ranked_diseases.disease_name: Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia due to 21-Hydroxylase Deficiency
ranked_diseases.explanation: This condition fits the hormonal profile, including decreased cortisol and increased ACTH, due to impaired steroidogenesis. Elevated prolactin and estradiol can occur due to compensatory mechanisms.
Decreased cortisol and increased ACTH are hallmark features. Elevated prolactin and estradiol may result from secondary hormonal imbalances.
Typically presents with hypogonadism and decreased testosterone. Elevated prolactin and ACTH could be secondary to hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction.
Increased prolactin is a primary feature, which can suppress testosterone production. Elevated ACTH and decreased cortisol may indicate secondary adrenal involvement.
Characterized by low cortisol and high ACTH. Elevated prolactin and estradiol may occur due to associated hormonal dysregulation.
